title: 108_hr1800
content: The policy of the United States is to end animal suffering caused by steel-jawed leghold traps by prohibiting their import, export, and interstate shipment, along with fur from animals trapped in such traps. Prohibited acts and penalties are outlined in the legislation. It is illegal to import, export, or transport fur or steel-jawed leghold traps in interstate commerce. Selling or acquiring traps in violation of the law is also prohibited. Violators face imprisonment and other penalties. Violating rules set by the Secretary under the Act incurs penalties. For the first offense, imprisonment for up to 5 days or a fine under title 18, United States Code, or both may be imposed. Subsequent violations may lead to imprisonment for up to two years or a fine under title 18, United States Code, or both. The Secretary will reward individuals who provide information leading to a conviction under the Act with half of the fine paid. Government officials are not eligible for these rewards. Enforcement measures are outlined in the Act, including penalties for violating rules set by the Secretary. The Act is enforced by the Secretary, who can use personnel and facilities from other agencies. Import and export violations are treated as customs law violations, with penalties enforced under the Export Administration Act of 1979. Enforcement of the Act is carried out by the Secretary using authorities from other agencies. Export violations are enforced under the Export Administration Act of 1979, allowing for detention, inspection, and seizure of packages suspected of containing articles in violation of the Act. The Secretary can detain, inspect, and seize packages suspected of violating the Act. They have the authority to make arrests without a warrant if there is probable cause, and to execute warrants issued by a judge for enforcement of the Act. The Secretary can detain, inspect, and seize packages suspected of violating the Act. They have the authority to make arrests without a warrant if there is probable cause, and to execute warrants issued by a judge for enforcement of the Act. Any article of fur or conventional steel-jawed leghold trap taken in violation of this Act shall be subject to forfeiture. Any article of fur or conventional steel-jawed leghold trap taken in violation of this Act shall be subject to forfeiture to the United States, with provisions for seizure, forfeiture, disposition of property or proceeds, remission or mitigation of forfeitures, and compromise of claims following applicable laws. The provisions for seizure, forfeiture, and compromise of claims under this Act apply to seizures and forfeitures incurred under this subsection. Enforcement duties can be performed by the Secretary or authorized officers. The Attorney General may seek injunctions. The Attorney General may seek injunctions against violators of the Act. The Secretary of Commerce, Treasury, and other relevant agencies must cooperate in enforcing the Act effectively. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "article of fur" refers to furskins or articles made from furskins. The term "conventional steel-jawed leghold trap" describes a device designed to capture animals by snapping closed on their limb. The term "customs laws of the United States" refers to any law or regulation enforced by customs authorities. The term "import" means to bring into the United States. The term "interstate commerce" has a specific definition in US law. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary has the authority to create rules for implementing the Act, which will become effective one year after its enactment.
